At the end of the movie, our so-called hero slowly transformed/mutated into an alien...

Well, if this is the movie of the year for such many people... maybe I was born into a wrong century.

title: Skip the first 30 mins
review: I'd heard and read nothing but rave reviews for District 9, even from a stranger standing behind me in the Red Box line who whispered "great pick, you'll love it!". But within the first five minutes we were convinced that once again, we were completely out of sync with the general movie viewer's tastes. First of all, I don't find documentary style movies particularly enthralling, and secondly, the ghettos of Johannesburg hardly makes for interesting or beautiful cinematography. Add an entire cast of total unknowns with sometimes difficult accents to understand, and we thought are they (people in general) kidding? But for some reason we kept watching, and just as I was about to hit 'stop' on the DVD player (about the half hr. mark), the documentary thing ended and an actual movie with characters and a plot kicked into gear. From there it took off and held us on the edge of our seats throughout the entire rest of the movie. We actually cared and rooted for these insect looking aliens and the interesting relationship with the human(s) that developed. District 9 really is an amazing accomplishment for such a small budget and really deserves the big budget treatment for the inevitable sequel.

title: Nice effort, but not that great.
review: The film could've cut about 20 minutes from the beginning and skipped the whole documentary bit following Wikus around, as well as all the interview bits describing what kind of a good man he is. Instead, they should've just used news bits to say that, and moved right into the story. The film was trying to balance the weird and strange dry humor of the South Africans in the documentary bits, but all those interviews of the people were completely unnecessary as nobody in the audience cares about what they had to say. The film was relatively low-budget for a sci-fi of its calibre and thus I suppose it needed filler to make it the length it is, otherwise it probably would've been about an hour long, which goes to show you that the filmmakers weren't too confident in the stories involving the characters who are actually in the action. For example, the 2 buddies are able to all of a sudden just smash and grab and escape without too much hassle. That scene could've been much more interesting had it explored more ways to bring out the relationship between the characters, including those in the military and the government, and it would've been nice to have seen much more of the city where the building stands! We don't even really find out how they get to the building! They just show up with an explosion, and that's that. The 2nd half is much better than the first, simply because we get to see much more action and sci-fi of the aliens, the ship, the robot and the computers. The story doesn't even explain how that alien battery liquid could've had the biochemistry to transform into what he is. It just happens, and that's it. The whole scene of the surgery is rather unimaginative, as we all know, if that sort of thing happened they would've knocked him out with drugs and gone right ahead with surgery/experiments. Anyway, overall it's a nice effort, but I wished they had not done the whole interview & documentary thing.

title: The moment that threw me out of the movie...
review:
We're half-way through the movie, and it's going well, when Wikus decides he's got to go back to his office to find the gel canister.

Here are the facts:

  • Wikus is a wanted man, who's face is plastered all over the news. - The alien 'Prawns' are eight feet tall ick-monsters. - The slum district is surrounded by heavily armed soldiers who's job it is to keep aliens IN the slum. - In twenty years, not a single alien weapon has been smuggled out of District 9.


BOOM! An explosion heralds the arrival of Wikus and his alien buddy who have somehow snuck out of District 9. In broad daylight. With alien weapons. And walked to downtown Jo-Burg to start blowing stuff up.

... I don't think so. :(

title: Mixed Review
review:
So, after seeing this movie, I actually liked it for the first few minutes after it was over. The next though, was a different story as I began to analyze.

First - if you're a sci-fi lover, you will enjoy this movie, if you are not, you still might actually like it due to the hypothetical and theoretical undertones regarding race, acceptance, "What ifs" The story takes a short peak at (What if the extraterrestrials we encounter to the first time and nothing of what we expect) they are lazy, gross, and don't enlighten our society - maybe even less of a race than we are.

So it is even more ingenious that this fill takes place in Johannesburg, one of the most racially and culturally historic place sin our world.

The CGI is absolutely incredible. The story is a little lack-luster, but the special effects are great enough to override the dull story.

The not so great: These aliens in the first few minutes are by far superior in physical strength - but at the end of the movie, they are being pushed around, jailed, and subdued like they can't fight back. I found myself saying "Comon, fight back aliens! 30 minutes ago you were kicking people to the moon and ripping the enemies arms off" - half way through the movie.

Secondly, this race - that is confined to slums typical of Africa - cant' do much put eat tires and jump all over the place. But all of a sudden, one of the members can make a super fuel and also have a supreme plan for getting his race back to the ship - so, 90 percent of the race cant figure it out, but one dude has all the answers - doest make much sense.

Also - the choice for some dork faced actor for the lead role is awful. I had no sympathy for the guy at all - and I lost interest in what might happen to him - I felt disengaged.

This is a good story as it takes a look at racial confliction and hate, and how unaccepting our society actually is - at a 3rd world level - and then adds some alien weaponry.

Still a good idea - but the story could have been enhanced. If Peter Jackson would have been the director, instead of taking a weak producer role - it might have made a better movie.

The alien weaponry is awesome, but th

title: Incredible!
review:
From the start I haven't been taking District 9 very seriously when I first saw the posters in the cinema after watching Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince with one of my best girlfriends this summer. I've totally forgotten about this movie till a couple of days ago and decided to finally watch it. Now I'm sitting here on the couch and really regret my first thoughts about this film. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE!

First, I really like the combination of documentary and fiction and in this case it's done to perfection. The only thing which I found a little confusing was the shifts between 'documentary camera' and 'fictional camera' and my mind was thrown a little out of the 'movie feeling'. Though this didn't last very long. You get use to it right away, also I didn't find it as disturbing as in many other films and most people probably wouldn't notice it at all so actually there's nothing to criticize. I can't point out anything about the animations. They are very convincing and composed beautifully with the real scenes and I haven't been able to point out any animation glitches at first hand. You don't sit and think it's 3D animations. The story isn't as unrealistic and 'American' far out as many other alien movies I've seen. The story takes place in Johannesburg and how many other Alien movies have ever done that? Nice idea. Like almost every other movie ever created District 9 also leave the viewer with some unanswered questions like "How can black liquid fuel mutate a human into a Prawn?" and "If the prawn's mother ship where able to move and beam things up by remote why did the prawn had to fly towards it?." But this isn't something you actually think about when watching the movie so it isn't that big a deal. I can't say anything bad about the actors. They make it really realistic and convincing that there's a 2.3 meter tall alien right beside of them. Also the actors speaking to the camera about Wikus, great work!

What can I say? I've given District 9 10/10 stars because it's a brilliant movie. Peter Jackson has done it again and Clinton Shorter has also done a great piece of work! So to all of you bored by reading this: Put on a smile and watch or re-watch District 9! It's incredible!

title: One of the best, if not the best movie i have ever seen
review: In short this movie is utterly amazing. This film captures almost every human emotion into one movie. there were parts of this movie were i could have started crying, and other part were i wanted to jump out of my seat and start shoot guns with them. the way the director was able to put both aspects into this movie is amazing. the movie ended i was speechless. it is so visually pleasing, unlike the other CGI movies out now, like transformers and the new terminator, the CGI look real, its not all shiny and flawless its gritty and textured. this movie portrays us, humans, exactly correct. it shows us what our real reaction would be like. i urge anyone and every one to give this movie a chance. if you watch this movie i guarantee you will enjoy it.

title: Magnificent! The greatest standout Sci-Fi film of the decade.
review:
I will start by saying, if you haven't seen this film yet, do so immediately. I won't spoil any of the storyline, I just advice you to see it.

Now this movie is set in the present or at least the not to distant future. A alien mother ship hovered over the city of Johannesburg in south Africa and the crew was brought down to the city. the ship was malfunctioning and the aliens who knew how to drive it was either killed or refused to reveal their identity. Soon of course the "temporary" living areas for the aliens becomes a slum, and can literally be called a ghetto. The movie is shot like it's a documentary and is centered around Wikus Van De Merwe played by Sharlto Copley. now I'm gonna stop here because i don't want to spoil any more.

The acting is great, the CGI is amazing. The movie is incredibly realistic and believable. I really don't know what more to say, it just looks amazing. Only warning is that it's a very adult film. it's not your typical action space adventure. it's a bit gritty and dark but that is what makes it so believable. it will evoke emotions but it's no action adventure, but I'm pretty sure you're aware of that.

All I can say this movie gets a 10/10 from me.And it is one of the best Sci-Fi films of the decade.

title: Something different in scifi
review:
District 9 is uneven in places but basically a very innovative, enjoyable movie.

The documentary style perfectly suits the near-future world where aliens have visited the planet and been coralled into townships around Johannesburg. Obviously the whole premise is based on Apartheid South Africa's treatment of its native population, and this really gives another level to the movie.

The lead - Wikus Van Der Merwe - is the best anti-hero in any movie I've seen in 20 years. The bumbling fool who is given an important job because of family connections is perfectly played. There are laughs aplenty - particularly if you have any knowledge of South Africa and its inhabitants - and the plot and pacing are really tight.

At the end District 9 does succumb somewhat to Matrix-style shoot-em-ups, but is redeemed by the bittersweet ending.

All in all, a remarkably original and entertaining flick.

title: district Nine sets a new standard of brilliance
review: Sharlto Copley reminds of a young Robert De Niro in this minimalistic masterpiece. Peter Jackson must have been amazed and so excited when he read this brilliant script by Neill Blomkamp (who normally works as an animator effects man)& Teri Tatchell.Movies like this only come once upon a long long time. I had to watch it several times to know what makes this movie so special. in the beginning you think "oh no another fake documentary, but the unique script and great play of the actors, makes it so divine to watch.And which would be a greater place for this futuristic mythology to take place, than Johannesburg. Hope the sequel will match up to this special art piece.

title: Unexpected brilliance!
review:
Firsty, as a South African I actually hate South African cinema. It was always third-rate rubbish in my opinion, lacking the slickness and production values of its Hollywood counterparts. Secondly, I *really* hate films with any hint of shaky camera-work.

So it was with great uncertainty and low expectations that I went to see a film produced in SA that reportedly contained hand-held footage, having only seen the poster beforehand (somehow I've missed any promotions while living in the UK).

How wrong could I have been? Apparently very, very wrong indeed! I'm not going to rehash any plot here, but I'll just say this: if you want your faith restored in cinema, go and see this film! If however you are partially brain-dead, have the intelligence of a 10-year old, or prefer watching moronic action movies, stick with Transformers.

My only grumble is that this movie's success will ultimately be its downfall. Many a good movie's legacy has been ruined by bad sequels, and I can already picture Sony lining up the likes of Bruckheimer or Bay to produce a dire follow-up. Which would be a shame, because this film deserves far, far better.

title: Horrible Main Character/ Well Conceptualized Aliens - Mixed Bag
review: After good word of mouth from work and a sky-high average vote, decided to check out "District 9" in the theater. Overall it was a mild disappointment given the expectations. Went in knowing very little. Starting out what really bothered foremost was an absolutely grating, idiotic protagonist dumbed down and really single-handedly written as to almost sink the picture. He doesn't think, wails and complains, and mixes what sounded like Australian and Dutch accents on his English all while cussing feverishly. Acting isn't the problem here as newcomer Shalto Copely acts his heart out, but the writing is a joke as writers throw logic and reason to the way-side in exchange for shoot-em-up action and foolishness. Ever watch really bad horror movies where cheesy characters do ridiculously thoughtless things? Well you get that here unfortunately too. Had the protagonist been created more cerebral instead of such a twit the movie would've made it to at least solid footing. It has a fabulous alien concept and rendering as well as a decent plot. Minor grumbles include how one-track the "evil weapons" corporation was, the now heavily heavily clichéd in all types of movies single female voice singing screaming "drama", and the use of "News and Interviews" as sort of a pseudo-documentary which frankly detracts and distracts from story-telling. District 9 had potential to make it to much greater heights as a lot of effort and thought has obviously been put into details of effects, locations, costumes, dialects, languages and sociology of what's going on. It's executed marvelously. But At it's core it's too much of a violent shoot-em running amok - rewriting is needed. Worth a watch though for the spectacle of it all.

title: Neil Blomkamp's debut feature film is a sterling effort.
review:
Neil Blomkamp's debut feature film is a sterling effort. The South African director's talents were first noticed when he made short film Alive in Joburg, and it didn't take long for Peter Jackson to hire Blomkamp to both direct and write District 9, a full length version of the aforementioned short. Blomkamp obviously wasn't overawed by the prospect. D9 is one of the freshest and most original sci-fi films to hit our big screens in a very, very long time. With a hint of comedy, a splash of drama and two big cups of action, science fiction has rarely been so rewarding.

With a meagre budget of only $30m you would expect there to be some shortcuts taken with the special effects but wouldn't you know my surprise when I found the CGI to not only be seamless but inventive to boot. The disgusting 'prawn' aliens are a sight to behold, their slimy faces and emotional eyes are perfectly executed and they interact with the actors fluently. I was shocked to learn that no physical effects or makeup were used to create the creatures such was there realistic appearance. Those who have seen Jackson's earlier film Bad Taste will see the definite influence he had on Blomkamp when it comes to the amusingly gory deaths in the final scene.

Lead actor Sharlto Copley has never acted before yet his transformation from bumbling idiot to South African Rambo (via outlaw on the run) is highly believable. The accent can sometimes cause unwanted laughs but I reckon Blomkamp and Jackson knew this already and subsequently turned the joke on us, the choice of humorous dialogue designed to ham up the Efriken accent proves this.

I didn't notice it until I was walking out of the cinema but D9 also features one thing seldom seen in a movie that also features exploding heads and grotesque aliens: a remarkable story. Blomkamp and Terri Tatchell have crafted a tale that incorporates messages of racial discrimination (most apparently the Apartheid) and profiteering, but never do they rub it in our face. Instead they choose to allow the audience to get involved as much or as little as they want. Don't want to think about the issues? Well sit back and enjoy the glorious action. Like a bit of deeper-thinking in your sci-fi's? You're covered too. No-one is left out and this is what will make D9 a long term favourite like genre classics Alien and The Thing.

I wait with baited breath on what Blomkamp decides to do next, but in the meantime directors Michael Bay (Transformers 2), Stephen Sommers (G.I. Joe) and McG (Terminator Salvation) should be taking notes: this is how you entertain an audience.

4.5 out of 5 (1 - Rubbish, 2 - Average, 3 - Good, 4 - Excellent, 5 - Classic)

title: Earthlings, don't miss this film!
review:
I have read many critiques about this movie and let me say when it comes to saying whether this movie is great or not it could just easily be both. Prepare to watch a 'LOVE IT' or 'HATE IT' movie.

In my opinion this was another great sci-fi. A superb production by Peter Jackson with great direction that shows the movie as if it was a National Geographic documentary but it never stops being a real movie.

There isn't just action and amazing, seriously amazing special effects, 'District 9' has an interesting script more realistic than many sci-fi scripts I've seen.

We are not talking about a Hollywood super sci-fi production like 'Transformers' or 'Star Trek', however when it comes to entertaining the public and keeping you at the edge of the seat 'District 9' has nothing to envy those films.

It is not an action movie where everything you see is human fighting aliens non stop and a blood shed, quite the contrary there is a lot of interesting dialog and realistic scenarios, nonetheless you will see some mayor action and very brutal combat. I personally loved the equilibrium between good action scenes but also dialog and quality.

The acting is not one of the primary good points of the film, yet Sharlto Copley (main guy) did a pretty good job for a man that is not commonly scene on screen.

I gave this film a well deserved 8 stars and frankly I recommend anyone to watch it and I would certainly watch this twice.

title: The key action Science Fiction film of the decade
review: Distict 9 is a true cinematic treat. As the trailers show, it has a documentary feel to it. It has very fast editing, and that is what makes it intriguing from the opening scene. The creatures are amazing. The effects and realism that they bring is something that is rare upon films these days, and while this film does bring up some memories of other films like Transformers(effects-wise, not quality wise thank god) and Cloverfield, the effects in this film go beyond of those films. The story is a conventional action film, where you have your hero and then the side character, in this case the extraterrestrial, but the film executes the story in a more unique and rare way. The editing, the camera-work, and the documentary style all raise it up above other action/ sci-fi films of this decade. Sharlto Copley gives a great performance, and he creates a character we feel for. The sound effects in this film remind me of the sound effects of Cloverfield. AMAZING! And I think the sound effects in this film are even better, because of the sound of the alien language and their communication. Just amazing. This reminds me of those classic alien VS Man films, and it is sure to become a sci-fi classic.

title: Awesome movie
review: District 9 does what a lot of movies claim to do but don't - it stays interesting and exciting right to the end. The movie actually seems like someone with a sense for story was involved in the script writing for once. It's refreshing after having paid to see a list of movies that promised these things over the last while and did not deliver even in the remotest sense. If you read, and want a movie that doesn't have you sitting in a theater embarrassed that you've been sucked into being there...and by that I mean terrible films like Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, Inglourious Basterds, Terminator Salvation, X-Men Origins, and the written-for-slow-twelve-year-olds list goes on ... than you should see this. It's awesome. Really. Best movie I've seen in a while at a theater...the only good movie I've seen in a while at a theater.

title: A great alien movie since Alien (1979)
review:
I've never seen so many critic films being produced and consumed by the masses as in the last few years. Movies that disseminate political and social issues disguised as action, fantasy or fiction. It's the old story, using allegories and metaphors the audience captures the idea without being blocked by their own prejudices. Disctrict 9 (2009), Watchmen (2009), Cloverfield (2008), V For Vendetta (2005), 28 Days Later (2002), 28 Weeks Later (2007), X-Men (2000)... are some of the last examples of important subjects discussed and disguised into pure entertainment. That's really clever.

Disctrict 9 is pure entertainment, but also a very different way to feel how humans can be so mean and cruel. The subject here is not about aliens or the probability of any invasion (even if it can also be a probability), but yes to discuss what's the worst of us. For sure the movie is a clear reference to what happened in South Africa in late 40's and what is called Apartheid, but just replacing black people for aliens. But if you replace again aliens for any kind of people or community, the main subject would not change in any way comparing to all that's happening and ever happened around the world. That's why this movie can be entertaining, but also a very interesting way to discuss current matters.

The movie itself takes the primal idea of movies such The Blair Witch (1999), REC (2007) and Cloverfield (2008), and also from games like Halo and Half Life. Like those movie references, there're no familiar faces or big names in it, which pumps the reality feeling of the events since everybody is unknown as in fact it would be in reality. There are some moments that you just can't understand why things are happening that way, for example, when Wikus uses the robot armor. That's nonsense, but it doesn't mess with entire movie or the rest of the idea.

District 9, above it all, is a great alien movie that I haven't seen since Alien. Cloverfield is also very interesting, but District 9 intensifies the idea and gives you another point of view of things.

title: Good... BUT not epic!!
review:
District 9 could be one of the most epic sci-fi masterpieces, but the PLOT HOLES just ruined it! Examples:

  • The director could present us some alien background story, besides the alien's planet have 7 moons instead of 1..lol... We're never told why the aliens landed on earth, if the only thing they needed was their fuel (that can be encountered in their pieces of technology), why didn't they do that in the first place before landing on earth???


  • Someone here on IMDb said: "why would fuel for a ship genetically modify someone to turn into an alien"... this is not a plot hole... they said in the movie that fluid is made from the aliens DNA... in that way their technology only works if the user is alien... and if the fluid had mutagenic agents, the transformation is possible (Why not? its a sci-fi show..lol)... the movie have plot holes, but common... lets no make even more...lol


  • Throughout the film the aliens show aggression, so they aren't entirely peaceful (thats why the humans no longer saw them with "good eyes" and began to oppress the aliens - fine, its a possible scenario). Yet the aliens don't start any uprising with their advanced technology. Why? why they never chose to fight back our oppression?? A reason is needed... they probable fear the humans atomic power... its possible...also when they were moved from their mothership to the Earth they left the guns there (some were illegally smuggled during the transfer), so there were few weapons to make a "revolution", BUT since the aliens were so human alike (in their attitudes and personality), why they never tried it? even knowing they would eventually lose the war!! at least they would take a very good revenge against the humans oppression and sent them a message... right? the main character make such a destruction using those weapons, the aliens could too!!


  • Why are almost all the aliens mindless drones, except the one guy who is actually technologically advanced??? its not supposed they being a super intelligent spacetraveller life forms??


  • Were there MNU agents in the ship working to obtain the technology it possessed?. I can't imagine that it would be just sitting there for 20+ years empty so that when the aliens flew up to the ship that they could just leave and no people would be on it...lol


  • what of the views of the humanitarians (which on any subject there are some)?? There was not any pro-alien ideas presented, so the documentary angle did not work in that aspect.


Its things like those above, that turn the movie not so good... those issues should be better explained and explored!! If there is going to be a sequel, i hope they explain those flaws... this sci-fi story have a lot of potential!!

Why?? Examples:

  • Its unique... its a different perspective about Humans Vs aliens!


  • The way the perspective switches from mock documentary style to standard third person certainly contributes to it. "Real" news footage and interviewers tell the story in retrospect, as the events of the movie have already occurred when they are being interviewed. I think it all added to the realism of the experience and always manages to stay fresh and surprising throughout. The atmosphere is bleak, dark and realistic, actually making me believe this thing can actually happen here on Earth.


  • It's about betrayal, loyalty, trust, relationships, and sacrifice. It can actually be pretty deep and thought provoking with many themes floating around. The story is really a fresh, gritty, original concept, which is good to see nowadays. While the creatures can be most readily described as monsters, though they are like us. Family and friendship are still important ideals in their world. The film explores a fine line between human emotions and monsters. With all the selfishness, hatred, and greed within us, maybe we are the real monsters or at least that's how it can be perceived.


  • Awesome CGI, great action and godlike alien weapons(if you guys ever played Unreal (PC Game), you know what im talking about)


  • The action is not passed in America... FINALLY!! it was a very good idea placing us, viewers, in another set besides Hollywood!!


  • The story moves at an incredible pace and the acting... WOW... just awesome, specially the main character Wikus (Sharlto Copley).. he is a revelation and one of the most memorable aspects of the movie.


I recommend it... Sci-Fi fans will definitely enjoy it! I give it 6.5 to 7 stars! Plot holes are a disappointment, but there is no reason to give the movie 1 star only because of that...LOL, if this is a 1 to 3 stars movie than its impossible to rate Dragon Ball Evolution because there is no negative scale on IMDb (Unfortunelly... but you guys get the point)!

title: Must See - A compelling, original piece of writing!!!
review:
I, probably like many others was not expecting much from this film - the trailer was very short and the idea was far fetched. The only reason for viewing this film was the high ratings on IMDb.

Wow, was I shocked. The trailer of this film shows a snippet of the actual film, probably accumulating the first 20 mins of the film before we actually get into a great, original, compelling piece of film and artistry! I don't want to give the game away but the idea is new and fresh throughout the whole film. The shooting style is fresh. The South African language is fresh. My only annoyance was the way that the lead character swore. I never want to hear anybody say "Fooking" again - in fact, it became comical by about the 4th time. This film has a somewhat unserious tone to it and certainly doesn't take itself seriously.

Overall, 9/10.

title: Not a feel good movie...
review:
District 9 is a fast paced movie which introduces you to a main human character that is not entirely likable though generally sympathetic. You also identify a specific alien and through him find more 'humanity' in the otherwise animal-like aliens. Through the human's story we learn the basic background about the alien arrival and follow his experiences leading a team that plans to move the aliens.

The movie is not filled with suspense, you can see where things are going pretty easily and not too much surprises the audience but there is good deal of yickiness and goo and a feeling of tension and urgency. You do not need to be a science fiction or alien fan to enjoy this movie. The story is extremely subtle in its commentary. There is an obvious apartheid comparison but if you have kept yourself informed about African history and refugee camps there and around the world you will draw comparisons between the horrible things that are done to and by the aliens and humans that live with/near the camps and real life events. If you aren't interested in the social commentary the movie moves quickly and has action and ends with a giant question mark leaving the opening for your own conclusions or possibly a sequel.

I found the movie to be unsettling and still entertaining. I would highly recommend it to any but the most squeamish people.

title: Disctrict 9 -
review:
There is a lot to say about this movie, as it has to be one of the best sci-fi films I've ever had the chance to see. First of all, don't expect it to be some kind of Star Wars or Star Trek not even a common alien movie. This is completely different. The aliens live among human population and they are treated like scum, living in deplorable conditions like a lot of human beings actually live nowadays. So yes, they're aliens, but they're mostly humans with another skin, because they have FEELINGS, which is something that it seems to be always forgot when it comes to this type of movies. Why do aliens have to be cold as ice and appear operating with high-tech machines and computers? Of course they are technologically more advanced than we are, because they come from space with an enormous spaceship, but they act like humans would act if they were in this trouble.

It can't be classified as a drama, because it has a lot of action, but I can't say it's an action film because there's a lot of emotion and depth in it, so it becomes a lot more than only an action movie. What am I talking about, then? I'm talking about a mixture of styles, which makes the experience really unique and helps the personal immersion. Also, I have to add that Wikus is a great character who seems to be a coward at the beginning and ends like a hero, not because he is right with all he does or because he solves "all" of his problems (better see the movie to get this), things that don't happen, but because he is, in the end, a strong person and fights for his life and for the rights and lives of others.

My advise? Go see it, District 9 is much more than it seems.

title: Men in black meets alien nation.
review:
The first hour of the movie was meant to be funny. I was a funny mockumentary. The accents are very thick..of everyone. (Not all south Africans have such a thick accent, just some.) Vicus was not the brightest...etc.

I think a lot of people are missing the satire/ irony of aliens living in District 9 in South Africa until 17 years ago. Non-white South Africans were forcefully moved from one districts. e.g. district 6 to another district until the 1980s.

These apartheid laws etc. were mostly implemented and followed through by afrikaans people ( white people with the thick accent, Vicus van der Merwe is such a very typical Afrikaans name the other one is Kobus.) The awkward scenes are really funny and meant to be funny. Also the scenes where he gives candies to aliens / pops their eggs is very funny dark humor.

Comedy needs to be added to genre! so make it: Action <> Drama <> Sci-Fi <> Thriller AND comedy

If you don;t get this you might miss a * or ** from the movie and the first half might seem a bit boring. I find it is much more funny then Men in black actually. I could have watched 3h of the first part.

Please don;t expect another THE MATRIX / TERMINATOR / YOUR SCIFI MOVIE HERE experience. It will NOT WOW you in that way. I think it was also not that rounded off with the best sound tracks, best cast etc. But since it was so different to anything I have seen before, had no famous stars to support it, I still give it 9 stars.

title: Excpected "Ok" got "Amazing"
review:
District 9 starts out in a very cool interview type of way which you may not realize that the interviews are starting to skew across "before" & "after" the time line and it is not until the end of the movie which you can actually decipher what some of the people are explaining.

The main character in this movie does a great job, and has an amazing change by the end of the movie. It's full of twists and you'll almost always be on the edge of your seat.

I would recommend this movie to ANYONE who is simply going to the theaters no matter what their movie-genre preference may be. There is so much to pull from it, an incredible storyline, full of action, etc etc...really whatever you'd expect out of a great movie District 9 has it.

Do yourself a favor and check out this movie.

title: Not that bad.
review:
First off, note that this film mostly consists of standard ingredients we've encountered in so many books and films over time. There's the ghetto situation, inhabited this time by stranded aliens but which you could as well replace with an Indian reservation or a slum of undefined location, the unholy mingling of corporate interests with politics, where the former apparently dominates all, and finally the classic anti hero, a thorough opportunist who, unwillingly, is forced to finally take a stance one way or the other. Then, to provide for the action as well as a personalized look on it, two basically independent events - the forced relocation of the ghetto and the attempt of a chief alien to repair a hidden drop ship and maybe escape earth for good - are thrown together to take us through enough melee to keep our senses busy. That's really the whole story already.

Add to that this being shot in a pseudo documentary style, with the obligatory, constantly swaying and sickening camera, hectic cuts also to pseudo news coverage, pseudo surveillance camera footage, pseudo whatever, and you'd agree that the whole piece hardly deserved mentioning safe maybe some notable special effects. But provided one can stand some heavy handed swear fests and blood splatter, I still think this film offers some nice twists which maybe don't make it a great one but still fairly likable.

One of them is that the lead act is basically an unknown actor but still does really, really well. Don't know about you guys, but I'm so thoroughly tired of big shot Hollywood names of the Christian Bale and Russel Crow kind and their polished but unaffectionate performances that I'm deeply grateful for each fresh face that comes up and does well. This is especially noteworthy because a large part of his job here actually is vocal work. And not some accent he had to master and would go brag about later on talk shows how difficult that was, no rather all the moaning and grunting which make up a large part of the latter half of the film and give credibility to his suffering and turning into the stripped down, reduced human being and creature he finally becomes. And that's no joke. It's his, I'd say totally convincing, inarticulate vocal expressions which give this film some credibility, on the emotional side.

Then, the other nice twist is of course not the suppressed actually being the "better people", which is a common theme as well after all. It's also not the opportunistic coward becoming a full human being by being forced into their point of view, as he's abandoned and potentially exploited by his own people and really taken care of only by the supposedly violent underdogs. No, what I'm referring to is that fairy tale theme, where the prince, by a curse, is turned into a frog and will turn back again only after some condition is met which deeply relates to humanity. This is what basically happens here, the (anti) hero being turned into a creature and forced to stay that way for a prolonged period of time, thus being forced to face himself as he really is until "the curse" is lifted. This really connects nicely to those age old fairy tales one might remember from childhood and provides for a, well, sweet touch.

So altogether, though really not original in many aspects, I'd still recommend this film as providing some good entertainment albeit severely lacking on the cinematographic side, which seems to be a lost art these days. And as said, at least the lead act saves the show for me. An impressive debut of his, if it was one.

title: More To This Movie Than Meets The Eye
review:
I did not know what to expect when I saw this movie, but after watching it for a while I really really liked it.

I know a lot on here are saying it was terrible, I love the guy who said that it was an Englishman running around evicting the aliens, when in fact due to his total ignorance it was a South African. Anyone who paid attention in school knows that Johannesburg is in South Africa.

It's really embarrassing how ignorant most of us Americans are about the rest of the world, if most of us knew even a little about South Africa more may have enjoyed this movie.

So listen up fellow ignoramuses.

South Africa which is well known for having had Apartheid, i.e. legal discrimination against blacks, only being outlawed in 1984.

So it's not a stretch for them to treat aliens in the way they did.

This film had comedy, racism, violence, drama, a love story and a happy ending.

What more could you want?

title: Prawns Are Everywhere In This Realistic Sci-Fi Effort
review:
After seeing Sharlto Copley in the new Sci-Fi Film District 9, would highly recommend this movie to people who want to see a new well done film. I mention Sharlto Copley because his role is so central to this film that he basically carries the entire film. It is a great performance in any context.

Neil Blomkamp writes & directs this film and it is quite an effort. The film very much starts off as a documentary type of film with Sharlto Copley at the center going into the story of how an alien ship appears over Johannesburg, South Africa. It then goes through how humans invade the ship and move the aliens out of it and onto a colony known as District 9. The visuals are so realistic that you'd swear this is the real thing.

The documentary part of the film then smoothly transfers into 2 stories- one involving Sharlto Copley's character getting exposed to alien matter and evolving into an alien, & the other involving a couple of the aliens trying to manufacture fuel so they can leave & go home. There is a cover story for the film as well about the South African effort to relocate the alien colony into District 10.

The film is not done as a typical sci-fi film in that it is gritty and really feels like it is depicting real events. The film always sticks with the base cover story and leaves a wide open door for a sequel. It will be interesting to see if they do one since the main line related to this is "I will be back in 3 years".

The film is excellent at drawing characters & stories from different points of view together & relating all of them. In fact the documentary part of this film is done so well that it actually feels like better reporting than the real media can actually do. There are also some other stories & commentary I have not brought into this review. This film has a depth rarely seen in the Sci-Fi film genre.

title: Unexpected and original
review:
Clearly not your average Alien Invasion Movie crap, it was like a breath of fresh "air" for me, I really enjoyed it, and most certainly I will watch it again.

The SFX were good, sound was quite impressive, only thing I did not like that much, was the acting maybe, but then again, when watching this kind of movie, this does not count that much.

Actually it made me think on a possible real scenario, when mankind would get into contact with aliens, and this one, presented in this movie, seemed very possible to me.

The idea is original, and I believe a sequel is required.

I rate it 8.

title: alien underclass warriors
review: Ideologically, the main attraction here is the absolute and savage refutation of the individual-versus-the-corrupt-system cliché – you know, 'Mr. Smith Goes To Washington' and all that. When the anointed leader of the alien-concentration-camp operation (Sharlto Copley as a nondescript bureaucrat, a fascinating and brave choice for an action movie protagonist) starts physically embodying the error of the us-and-them approach to the alien invasion, he is not only deposed from his seat of power, he's sent straight to the basement, where the secret labs are. Not only that, he remains an opportunistic rat bastard almost to the very end of his mutation. Still though, as an allegory it's pretty messy. If producer Peter Jackson wanted this to be his 'Intolerance' – atonement for the unga-bunga racism of his 'King Kong' – then he kind of goofed by making all the African ganglords into grinning cannibals. Rejecting gauzy sentiment is one thing, but those scenes play like Nollywood with a budget, which is the last thing the world needs On the other hand, this is exactly the kind of ideological blind spot that is all over the place in all but the very greatest of classic speculative science fiction, and THAT is the pigeonhole this movie fits best. It's not a metaphor, it's a specific imagined situation: what happens when the 'alien invasion' of yore smacks up against late capitalism's grotesquely elephantine military-industrial complex? This is a compelling rendering of that premise, even if they cheat by ditching the mock-doc conceit in the second act; it was really just a device to compress the exposition. And boy, is it ever compressed; the roller coaster moves fast enough to jump the gaps, holding steady until almost the very end, when a gratuitous bionic suit shtick provides one spectacle too many.

title: That rare thing - an alien film that actually makes you think
review:
District 9 is a highly engaging and thrilling alien film, and one of the few films of this genre which actually makes you sit back and think. With nods to The Fly, Robocop and even Black Hawk Down it was a film that I really enjoyed.

Using the perhaps unorthodox step of extra-terrestrials to make a poignant and striking film about racial tensions, but with enough explosions, action and hi-tech weaponry to avoid feeling too worthy...

I would seriously recommend trying to catch this film, and would whole-heartedly encourage you to avoid being too judgemental and just sit back, become absorbed and enjoy the ride.

title: Gronk!
review:
District 9 is told from the perspective of a retroactive documentary, with the actual movie filling in the events between the commentaries. When the movie initially began, I wasn't sure if this was going to be any good with this style of storytelling.

I was pleasantly surprised.

I think that part of the joy of this movie is to discover the storyline for yourself, and so I will not rehash it here. Suffice it to say that once the interesting plot line gets going it REALLY gets going, with characters that I found I cared about in the end, even Wickus whom I didn't really like at the beginning. The ending was rather touching and left the door wide open to a sequel that I would be sure to see as well.

I give this movie an 8.5, it is worth more than the price of admission.

title: The Sci-fi, Alien genre is reborn!
review:
Thank you Neill. Thank you Peter.

Neill being the revelation director/writer and Peter being our much-loved LOTR-fame producer.

First of all, let's be clear: this is not your usual, re-hashed, seen-it-before sci-fi flick. It's hardcore, it's heavy and one could (easily) argue it's damned deep.

Having been concocted by a South African, the whole idea is scarily analogous not only to the atrocities of Apartheid, but also carries unsettling echoes of the worst events of WWII, ie. concentration camps and "experiments." It is a vivid and effective indictment of Man's Inhumanity To Man, except it is represented in Man's Inhumanity To Aliens. Oddly, and hats off for pulling this parable off so effectively using ugly aliens, it works magnificently.

I do not want to spoil ANY of the plot, because I really think this is one of those flicks that should be seen ASAP and with as little background noise and info as possible.

It's been said that it works on several levels, it has something for everyone. It's touching, violent, shocking, scary, clever, coherent, original, but above all, throughout it is brilliant.

Not many films make you feel as alive as this one. It makes you cheer for the main characters, human and alien. It makes you think. It makes you sink into your seat with some of its more shocking scenes.

It does take a little while to really get going, but once it does, WOW! It's a non-stop visual and sensory delight! Some scenes were so impacting, I couldn't help myself emitting my audible approval or shock.

I cannot wait for "District 10". Which I hope will materialise one day soon...

title: Entertainment and Action
review:
If you like interesting ideas wrapped up in a fast, clever & quick flick, if you like action, it's here. If you like gore & gushing geysers of gook, they are all here. District 9 is great, and will definitely become a classic sci-fi movie.

Other reviewers covered the comparisons to Blade Runner - I'd agree, but would give BL more points. But this is more FUN. Other reviewers went into the intellectual part of this - but this is more FUN.

It's well-crafted, fast, has great editing, decent character development, and most of all, we viewers find ourselves shifting our POVs and allegiances naturally - the other becomes us. A well done trick, adroit and effortless.

There's other stuff, like how easy it is for the powers that be to devise an interpretation of events/people that has nothing to do with reality, but which yet becomes the dominant reality. This is not labored over in the film, just a comment I'm making by the wayside, the one that's littered with prawns.

The CGI is phenomenal, the acting is good, the pseudo-documentary feel tells us there is someone in the future looking back at this time, who still doesn't know all of the aftermath. Sequel?

title: Finally, a new movie that exemplifies the title of "movie classic"
review:
I must say that even when I saw the first preview to this movie I knew that this movie would be at least mildly entertaining. After viewing it, I have no problem in saying that it makes my top ten list of greatest movies of all time and this is why: 1. the aliens: for the first time in the age-old genre of alien sci-fi, District 9 presents the audience with a new vision of aliens--not the creatures that attack or harvest humans, but rather the exact opposite. This movie actually makes the aliens seem "real" and in doing so give the audience a sense of emotional attachment towards them. 2. political background: this movie was, in essence, a dramatization of the actual events that took place in Johannesburg's District 6 with the forced removal of black Africans from their homes to keep them away from whites. I honestly believe that this movie showed apartheid in a way no other movie has and it also showed how evil humans can be, no matter what year we are in. 3. realism: this movie also made the aliens and the story seem believable. At the premise, humans were not sure what to think about an extremely large mother ship that lands on earth and then took in the aliens and went from trying to accept them to basically enslaving them in order to gain use of their weaponry. The scene when Wikus is used as a medical and biological experiment was done both emotionally and brilliantly. 4. actors: finally, this movie offers very good acting from a group of performers that had totaled less than 100 hours of previous acting. Shartlo Copley's first blockbuster was a huge success and I would not be surprised if he receives an Oscar nomination.

Finally, the ending was probably the weakest part of the movie. However, it did set up very well for a sequel and I would be interested to see if Jackson would consider a return of Christopher Johnson and how the plot line in that event would pan out. This movie was easily the best of the summer and one of the best sci-fi movies to come out in years. A must see and when released a must own.

title: 1st half looked like Borat, 2nd half much better
review: I don't think the following is a spoiler since I am being very general... But anyways: It is a good movie, but it could have been a great movie had it not been for the 1st half of the movie. I thought the 1st half reminded me too much of that Borat movie and the main character reminded me of the Borat character. The main character was kinda annoying to me due to the character not being as funny as intended. If you're into silly slap stick comedy, then you may find it funny-not to me though. I just kept wondering if he would get seriously injured by the aliens or not when attempting to evict them. That was the only suspenseful part during the 1st half of the movie. The 2nd part is where the action and suspense happens. I also wish there was more character development and background info on the other characters in the story, but I guess the writers are saving that for the sequel.

title: Blew me away - Great sc-fi film!
review:
I'm not going to get into a whole big review, let me just say, yes it has some plot holes. It starts off as a mockumentary and ends up a balls to the wall action film. Just go with it, and enjoy the excellent direction and outstanding special effects! Everything looks absolutely real.

There is a lot of dark humor in this film, I think some people are taking it way too seriously. I was cracking up and nobody else in the audience seemed to get the jokes (or maybe I'm just crazy). I'm not going to spoil any of the bits by going into specifics. There are also a lot of subtle references to other sc-fi films, and a lot of Peter Jackson's style in this movie. If you are a fan of his early work, you'll know what I mean. It's quite gory in parts, so if you have a weak stomach it may get to you at times.

I'll be going to see this again. Go see it, just don't take it too seriously!

title: Yayyyyy Aliens!
review: At first the shaky camera thing seemed dismaying. Gigantic alien ship hovering over Africa for months then we humans forcing our way in to find 1000's of "worker" bee aliens. OK, so the leaders had died is the explanation. So we build a slum tenement for them then treat them like bugs and call them Prawns because they look like humanoid shrimp. Your heart goes out immediately for them. Even the "nice" guy that interfaces with them for the eviction is a prick, at least until he understand their predicament from experience. The intelligent alien and his son are VERY endearing and capture much more sorrow from me than any human in the movie. Heck, the aliens even have greedy pawn brokers preying on them. One sad scene is when the military industrial complex is testing one of their weapons on a Prawn and the poor thing is looking around with fear. Pretty funny that the Prawn love eating cat food. Effects in this are stunning, action is compelling, though this is a rooster film and the chicks will enjoy it less. Pretty violent and gooey. It really captures and holds on to your interest. Particularly tantalizing is when you realize (from visuals) that these "dumb" alien bugs are actually far advanced over humans in their technology. This will obviously have a sequel. Can't wait.

title: Not your average human-meets-alien movie.
review:
I went to watch this thinking it was just going to be another action movie with a horrible script that would help me kill some time. Was I ever wrong.

This is an incredibly well made movie. With Peter Jackson (director of such heavyweight hits as The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy & King Kong) as the primary producer of the film it was no surprise that the special effects were amazing and that the story was riveting as well. The way the movie was shot is pretty unique and keeps you interested every step of the way.

What got me the most about the movie was the light in which humanity is sometimes shown: self serving, greedy, violent bullies and yet there are also moments of self sacrifice and tenderness. Some of the actions of the humans towards the aliens made me feel ashamed for being human. Yes, it's that moving of a script!

Obviously I wasn't the only one that liked the movie because on opening weekend the movie grossed $37 million and has so far grossed more than $80 million dollars. Not bad for a little indie flick.

If this is playing in your town I would highly recommend you go and see it. It's well worth the 12 dollars admission!

title: Classic allegory
review:
District 9 is an allegory of District 6 which occurred in Cape Town when the apartheid government forcibly removed 60,000 black habitants in 1965, declaring the zone a whites only residential area. It is the viewers attachment to the aliens, the segregation and discrimination taking place and the acceptance of that policy that is disturbing. Sadly, District 9 paints a very real picture of what would be, and sadly what is, in some countries. I would like to think that given such an event mankind would look past an opportunity for weapons and money, for that of intellectual advancement and inter-race development, sadly it is history that presents a very different picture.

Saying all that, this is an excellent film, certainly one of the best I have seen in the last couple of years and well worth seeing.

title: What a film
review: This film shows the human race in its full glory of our lack of tolerance and reminds us all how crap it is to be a human... - Great film... watch it! - if you like films that have a deep meaning then you will love this film, its about time someone did a film with a bloody good story line. well done! - not just full of FX, after watching it reminded me how weak we are. and how fast we are to give an opinion on something... so next time someone says there gay or disabled don't be so fast to give your opinion, because one day it might be you getting the opinions about you. and because i have to give 10 lines i will just ramble on, lol. it said comment not an SA... lol

title: Amazing. Those who don't like it are missing the big picture
review: it isn't just a regular sci-fi movie like most nerds had hoped, it symbolizes white vs black. it talks about how the white man thinks that they can take over any race that isn't white. this movie was intelligent and better than any other alien movie by a long shot. it wasn't poorly shot. its not like the cameraman was a monkey or something, no. the point was that it was suppose to seem like a true story to make people think about the situation and if we were put in it. it shows how the humans messed up and tried to take control and advantage of a race that they just assumed were lower than us. the acting was far from awful. i would rather have mediocre to good actors from the actual country of the movie over having huge famous actors putting on accents.

title: Great movie; perhaps the best for 2009
review: First we had movies like Terminator Judgment Day and Transformers and now G.I. Joe which personally didn't satisfy my pallet along with a few others not worth mentioning but this movie has it all, weapons, humor, violence, and the human monster which is a good wake up call that is much needed in the sense of noticing the similarities to what's going on in the current state of affairs with Terrorist propaganda. One thing that really got out to me was how big brother's eye in the sky was always there throughout the whole movie. It's touching in the sense of showing how people can change under extreme circumstances with the choice to do what's right before they fall completely out of grace. The only thing that I didn't like which could be considered as a major plot hole is how these 'prawns' where unable (or unwilling) to use their own weaponry and the reasons for this was not explained at all. But nevertheless, the effects were great and the story was original. It made me aware of certain things and that's a good thing. Go see this when you can.

title: Best Movie of 2009
review:
Honestly when I saw previews to this movie I was not that thrilled but this movie is way better then the preview makes it out to be and I will probably see this movie it least 1 more time before it go's to DVD.

This movie is a must see, but I must warn you, it is not for those of you with a weak stomach. This movie is gruesome! I went to see it with my girlfriend and she had to turn away several times because it was so gross! This movie reminds me a little bit of Aliens and a little bit of Predator. It reminds me of Aliens because this movie too is ground breaking, and it reminds of predator for 1 simple reason that I can almost guarantee you will notice.

title: Excellent on all levels
review: I found watching District 9 a completely satisfying experience. It's one thing when an arty independent film is complex and involving, but when a sci-fi action flick transcends its mainstream genre in the way District 9 does, that's great cinema. The last film that made me feel this way was the first Terminator back in 1984, such a completely unexpected and powerful experience. Completely entertaining and yet uncompromising in its complexity and what it expects of the audience. It's a miracle that this was the top grossing movie last week. One can hope that the success of this film will open the door to other creative minds that want to demand more of their audiences.

title: Plot holes - minor spoiler
review:
I enjoyed it, but several plot holes took out some of the endorsement. 1) They can't track a cell phone signal? Give me a break! (OK they eventually get around to it, but it takes forever).

2) The main character takes forever to discover he has the ability to open a can of whoop_ass on the bad guys, and even then he doesn't hold onto his weapon.

3) The bad guys are (as usual) horrible shots and even suspend shooting for dialog.

Still very much worth going. The cat food angle is fun and I am a bit ashamed that I enjoyed the aspect of home-boys in the hood gambling with the aliens. I wonder what Nigeria thinks about this one?

title: Surprisingly good.
review:
I went to see it knowing only the basic premise - that alien beings were being kept in a sort-of refugee center. And when I saw the first aliens, the first thought that popped into my head was, "They look a lot like PREDATORS." As someone else said earlier, this film "borrows" a lot from earlier science fiction classics. And that is why I took one star away from the film. Other than that, I was mightily impressed.

Actors didn't sound like "actors" - mouthing out meticulously scripted lines. The actors sounded like "regular people" caught up in a dilemma that strained the boundaries of humanity and humaneness. And the central figure who came in contact with the alien "liquid" substance was forced to choose between allegiance to two species.

Beyond that, I'll say no more since it might be construed as a "spoiler" comment. Suffice it to say that this film will satisfy every expectation of the science fiction fan and, in some cases, will exceed them. If you like science fiction (and have a strong stomach), you owe it to yourself to see this film.

title: Pretty good...!
review: One of my favorite things about this movie was how incredibly entertaining it was. A little ridiculous at times...sure.. but worth seeing. It kept my attention pretty much the whole time. (Ok.. it took about 10 minutes for me to get into this movie and the last 10 min or so dragged a bit but other than that, a good movie.) District 9 was very different than anything I have seen before. Usually I am not into alien movies. Saw the previews for this movie months ago and probably would have never thought to have seen it if I hadn't read all of the great reviews about it before hand. I am not surprised at how many people have liked this movie because it was well done.

title: I love this film.
review: Seriously. I love this film. Last year, two movies made me crazy, which were Iron Man and Dark Knight. This year, it's Harry Potter 6. Hangover, and this. Amazing action, great story, and touching. This will show Transformers and Terminator with GI Joe that a Sci Fi movie can have a story with amazing effects, that too with only a 30 million dollar budget. The background score is electrifying. The performances aren't the best, but they are believable. Which brings me to this: this movie is too believable, too realistic. You might feel a bit uneasy, but if you're emotionally strong, you can take it. Hats off to Peter Jackson to slapping the Sci Fi film genre back to it's senses.

title: Keep the Prawns Out
review:
So I was like really excited to see this film for weeks before it was released and then last Friday when it was released I ran out and saw the very first showing. District 9 is directed by a first time director, and produced by famed director, Peter Jackson. Just from the previews I knew I was in for a huge treat for the mind and the eyes, and you know what I was right! This movie is directed by a professional special coordinator, Neill Blomkamp, this happens to be the first film that he has ever directed. When his initial movie fell through Peter Jackson provided the money and the resources for him to bless the big screen with the phenomenal film, 'District 9'. I saw an interview with Neill Blomkamp in which he said that if the special effects were not up to par, he would quickly lose his audience. So in this film we are presented with extraordinary visuals, which are extremely believable. Many time through out this film, my jaw dropped open in suspense and surprise. For this movie is unlike anything I have ever witnessed in theaters. I have to give a huge amount of kudos to the director, for first time directors usually fail on their initial film, 'District 9' however is a huge success. I will buy this film probably on the first day it is released, and I will put it right there in my amazing movie collection with all my other sci-fi films. I usually rate films on, whether or not they have an impact in the cinema community, or if they will be quickly forgotten. I can see 'District 9' being remembered for a very long time. We have another first for this film; main character Sharlto Copley is a first time actor. In witnessing this film I would have assumed that he had been acting his whole entire life. Thus making this film, more enjoyable, strong, and surprising to watch his character Wikus Van De Merwe fighting for everything in his life that he loves. Many scenes are so hard to imagine that he's not a professional actor. The surprising amount of emotion portrayed by this character is hard to fathom. I enjoyed watching his work, for it really was a piece of art not to be overlooked. This movie has an incredible story line, written by the director Neill Blomkamp, many times towards the end, I was gasping in horror, that he might have made a spectacular film but didn't quite know how to end it. That wasn't the case at all, from beginning to end; I was surprised, shocked, and amazed at the impact of the story line on his film. Towards the end, there were times when I thought, "oh that's it, that's how it's going to end" then the story would twist in an opposite direction. It does this throughout the last quarter of the film probably about 5 times. 'District 9' has an immensely perfect story line with underlying political statements, of segregation, population, and occupying of an assembled area. Only with a twist to the story line in which Americans are not occupying a falling community, not even humans are, but an alien species. Most of the time, my film critiquing gets in the way of noticing subtle political points. However, I was very proud of myself for understanding it in this movie. The political statements in this film, is just another pro about this flick. It doesn't take away from the storyline it only emphasizes it. The special effects in this film were so up to date; I wondered how they ever managed to stay under budget. It was so realistic to watch it almost made be believe that somewhere hovering over Johannesburg, South Africa would be a huge space ship filled with cockroach looking extra-terrestrials. 'District 9' has an immensely perfect story line with underlying political statements, of segregation, population, and occupying an assembled area. Only with a twist to the story line in which Americans are not occupying a falling community, not even humans are, but an alien species. I recommend this movie to everybody. I saw this film on Friday, and I was initially going to go by myself, until my mom looked up the overall rating, and saw that it was getting a 9.2 on it's first day. So she came and witnessed it perfection with me on the first day at the first showing. I then took my little sister and my four little brothers, they also enjoyed it, on the following day I took my best friend, and he enjoyed it just as much as I did. So yes, I do recommend this film to almost everybody. I feel privileged to have been able to see this film and critique it. So in conclusion, I loved Neill Blomkamp's first film 'District 9'.

-Wannabeanalice- I have a running movie of the day blog if you would like to read it on myspace.

title: its good for a scifi fan
review: OK so this film is my first. i ain't 1 of these critics. am just joe bloggs giving my opinion. this is a film that provokes emotions. it could well be true but who knows (foil ballon). as for the actors then who should care as in this movie it stirs the imagination. as for the actors, what can i say other than watching it, i find it spot on. scifi is all about the imagination. well am short and sweet on this film. it made me want to join and say my tuppens worth. remember these r films and its what we need to escape from reality. am not 1 for mentioning names of all that but i am 1 for saying it is a good example of how us humans could behave. (do behave). this movie is just a perfect example underliying quality of our nature.

title: Not your typical alien sci-fi flick
review:
Because I had heard so much buzz about the film, I tried to not learn anything more. That helped, because as I watched the film, I didn't know where it was heading, and got nice surprise after surprise.

It's a shame that other writers, producers, and directors can't have visions like this. They spew out the same 'Transformers' and 'GI Joe' crap year after year, thinking CGI and explosions makes a good film.

Don't get me wrong-- 'District 9' has plenty of explosions and CGI, but they make sense, add to the visual excitement, and feel realistic. For a tiny budget (by Hollywood standards), they pulled off something amazing.

I honestly don't know if my fiancée would like this. I decided to watch this without her, knowing I'd probably like it. It's good enough for me to see again, and maybe I'll take her (she went to see 'The Time Traveler's Wife' with a friend instead. Without even seeing it, I'll bet I can tell you the beginning, middle, and end of that movie).

'District 9' seems ready-made for a sequel: 'District 10'.

If you enjoy intelligent, witty, well-made science fiction films, and can handle some gore, this is the movie for you.

title: Some good'ol Sci-Fi....
review:
As always let's start with the basics

Pros:

 Great Premise  Awesome Special Effects  Underlying commentary about the highs/low of human nature  Fantastic immersion in the atmosphere.  The Alien weapons were awesome they had a gravity guy even!

Cons

 Some weird parts  Some of the improvised dialog in combo with the thick accents was hard to follow at times.

This movie by far was the best Sci-Fi movie I've seen in a long time. It also shows-up every other big movie this year that had ridiculous budgets and we're mediocre at best. District 9 reminds us that it's still the acting, directing, and writing that really make a good movie. The main issue (in my opinion) that could drive some people away from the movie is the "gross" or "really weird" scenes here and there; for example: the Nigerians eating the aliens to try and get their power. However, if those things don't really irk you then it's all good. I thought the best attribute of the movie was how it immersed me in the atmosphere or "feel" of District 9 the grime, the smell, the violence, and all the other hardships that were forced upon the Prawns. I will say the violence was brutal but wasn't glorified or overdone like other movies. The acting in D9 was fantastic considering how much experience the cast had in fact, the absence of A-List stars added to the realism of the footage given everyone looked like a normal every-day person. In conclusion, if you like pure sci-fi then you should like this movie the aliens looked phenomenal, the premise is very original, the weapons were sick, and the final 20-30 min climax was spectacular.

-AX

title: Loved it
review:
This film was extraordinary. I found it to be very entertaining and the visual effects were breathtaking. I was very excited to see another Peter Jackson production and boy was I impressed. The whole movie has you on the edge of your seat wondering what could possibly happen next.

This is not a story about aliens in outer space trying to kill everyone, but a film about a race (the aliens) that along with any other race are segregated and forced to act out in order to survive. So this story is so much a Science Fiction film as it is a story about people and some core issues that the people of South Africa struggled with for so many years.

I think this film can be targeted to the person's throughout the world that do not really concern themselves with any issues dealing with people that are not in their immediate circle. This takes film and connects a mass audience to show you the issues on another scale. The core of discrimination and segregation are all the same, person's who are not deemed 'worthy' of our respect because of educational barriers or simply the color of their skin (or in this case DNA makeup) shall be treated like garbage. I think this film brings many different people's entertainment levels into one. Where one would not have found a story about an ordinary guy's shift from watching a fight to living the fight anywhere exciting, this movie brings you that entertainment aspect along with the dramatic story of how a world revolving around politics can be the greediest and most distrustful experience imaginable.

title: Grave Casting Error
review: Someone made a big mistake in making the aliens look like prawns. I had great difficulty in feeling any sympathy for prawns being mistreated. I eat them often myself. The movie as a metaphor for mistreatment of minorities would have been much more effective with humanoid aliens. Someone who resembles me can elicit much more sympathy.

title: 1.000.000 Times better than Avatar
review:
This movie could have won the Oscar considering the favorites were Avatar and Hurt Locker. In my opinion both did not deserve to even be nominated actually. Maybe after you watch District 9 you will think that even District 9 is not good enough to win the Best Movie Award but at least it deserved to be amongst the nominees, and it would not be an unfair Award to this Fantastic Film as it was to Hurt Locker or Avatar, if it had won.

What I like the most about the film is that it increasingly gains momentum throughout, starting out as a weird documentary, but then evolves into more mainstream thriller territory, before culminating in some thoroughly entertaining action set pieces.

If you were hoping for a lot of Human vs Alien action, wait for the second half where you will see just enough for the movie not to become a War of the Worlds crap.

I wish I had seen this movie before the Oscars because I would definitely be cheering for it!

title: A Revolutionary Science Fiction
review: This film is one the was of great interest to me. When i first heard about i thought it would be just another usual, 'aliens visit earth attempt to destroy it, human somehow win', movie. But it wasn't. It was one of the most original films i have ever seen. The idea of humans accepting to live with aliens was a very original idea. Although a little too violent, the visual effects are the real standout in this film. The way the humans and aliens blended together seamlessly in every scene was quite stunning. They really were deserving of an Academy Award. Another piece of brilliant originality from Peter Jackson was that the film, set the audience up to side with the aliens. A truly daunting task, that was achieved superbly. The film was seemingly set up for a sequel at the end, which would be much anticipated. District 9 is a very original and solid film. However, some of the violence in the film was rather excessive and may turn away some viewers.

title: Total Disappointment carried on the back of a slug
review:
From the previews, I expected District 9 to be a dark, suspenseful movie that would shock and frighten me. I was wholly disappointed.

From the beginning I did not find any of the movie believable, from the way the aliens acted (For instance, in one of the scenes with the gangs: how could an alien be so foolish to stop by for a second to have their head blown off, and worse yet, why didn't any of his companions stop and try to gain some measure of vengeance?) to the pseudo-government/paramilitary organization (which didn't have any intervention from other nations, as far as I could tell), I couldn't find this movie believable despite the decent SFX and camera work.

This might be forgivable if the movie had picked up the pace. Yet, for a movie that spans less than a week (in movie time), it seemed three times as long as that and it crawled at a slug's pace, and it was just as boring (not that I want to put down slugs), most of the time.

Finally, the end of the movie is far too anti-climatic to be satisfying and screams that there will be a sequel in tow, but I can't bother to care the least bit. If the story takes more than a movie's length to gain momentum, then I'm rather sure the sequel won't be worth watching.

title: Worst movie ever
review: Horrible acting, horrible plot, by far the worst movie ever.

title: Sci Fi is dead.
review:
The only interesting bit of the film was the fact that it took place after 'first contact' and 20 years on.

The characters weren't appealing, I didn't care what happened to any of them. I don't like talking heads and documentary style scenes in films either. News reports too.

24 hours eviction notice, over 1 million signatures. wtf?

The language the aliens used was supposed to be understandable by humans yet sounded completely inaudible to me, I tried to listen out for familiar 'words' or sounds when they did speak but couldn't catch a thing.

Other things I couldn't get my head around....selling a suit of armor for 100 tins of cat food, when you could, well, have just put on the armor and over powered the humans and nicked it. The 'prawns' being able to kick and kill a human to death in the blink of an eye but are completely over powered by 20 Nigerian outlaws with a few guns.

Far too many questionable gaps in the plot for me, i didn't care about what happened and couldn't wait for it to finish.

Overall, if you take films seriously, over the age of 25 and want real quality when you pay to go watch a movie...don't watch district 9.

I'm sure it will do well with kids though.

title: District 9 could have been a 9
review: District 9 had all the makings of a new generation of science fiction films. District 9 had a very interesting concept that could have explored human/alien rights issues and how human beings treat those they do not understand. While the idea was good, the script and the director failed to fully capture the mood that could have produced a very insightful film. District 9 was still an entertaining film. The acting was not the greatest, but it was better than the usual syfy movie of the week. The script was not on par with "Alien" but was better than the typical sci-fi movie and the direction was better than the average "direct from music video" directors we have seen in the past. There were too many holes in the script and the aliens did not receive the screen time that would have made this movie propel into a classic. The inhumanity to the aliens was touched upon, but should have been included more to have a feel for the life that the aliens had to live. Why did aliens with superior weapons allow themselves to be treated this way? Why did the ship come to Earth? How could millions of aliens allow themselves to be beaten and battered? These are things that could have been explored. I still enjoyed the film, but the hype is too much for an above average sci-fi movie.

title: Literally unwatchable
review:
I had to leave the theatre after half an hour because the "Blair Witch Project" camera-work was so awful that I was literally about to vomit on the theatre floor. The funny thing, is the way the plot was developing, it would have seemed perfectly acceptable to do so.

The story itself piqued my interest and I am curious to know how the plot turned out. On the other hand, the allegorical politics of the movie were so heavy-handed and sophomoric that I don't think I would have enjoyed the movie even had the producer sprung for a tripod.
